title: Why was Spanish colonization not successful? - Quora

response.answer_text: If we’re talking about in places like Mexico, Florida, South America and so forth. At least during the 16th - 18th centuries, they were not trying to colonize they were extracting commodities and shipping them home. They were not trying to really encourage a major immigration of Europeans to the new world. Other than overseers to manage the extraction/acquisition of mineral, food, and other commodities onto ships for transit largely and military to guard them and search for more things to acquire they had little civilian footprint. And didn’t seem to be interested in establishing one.
Not successful? what do you mean? They were the world power for 300 years after they fell Britain filled that hole. Your question needs more clairifcation, if you clarify it ill be willing to answer.
